title: Lloyd Austin
added: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as defence secretary on January 21st 2021, becoming the first African-American to hold the job.

title: Lloyd Austin
added: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as defence secretary on January 21st 2021, becoming the first African-AmericanPentagonChief.

title: Lloyd Austin
added: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as defence secretary on January 21st 2021, becoming the first African-American[[Pentagon Chief]].

title: Lloyd Austin
added: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as[[defence secretary]]on January 21st 2021, becoming the first African-American Pentagon Chief.

title: Lloyd Austin
added: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as [[UnitedStates Secretary of Defense]] on January 21st 2021, becoming the first African-American Pentagon Chief.

title: Lloyd Austin
deleted: Congress granted a waiver to Lloyd Austin serve as [[United States Secretary of Defense]] on January 21st 2021. If Austin is confirmed by the Senate, he will be the first African American Pentagon chief.

title: Lloyd Austin
added: [[Category:African-American members of the Cabinet of the United States]]

title: Lloyd Austin
added: In 1993, Austin returned to the 82nd Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, North Carolina where he commanded the [[505th Infantry Regiment (United States)|2d Battalion (Airborne), 505th Infantry]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Brooks|first=Drew|date=2016-04-10|title=Gen. Lloyd Austin Ends 41-year Army Career|url=https://www.military.com/daily-news/2016/04/11/gen-lloyd-austin-ends-41-year-army-career.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201209145111/https://www.military.com/daily-news/2016/04/11/gen-lloyd-austin-ends-41-year-army-career.html|archive-date=December 9, 2020|access-date=2020-12-11|website=[[The Fayetteville Observer]]|language=en|via=[[Military.com]]}}</ref> He later served as the [[Staff (military)|G-3]] for the 82nd Airborne Division. Following graduation from the [[United States Army War College|Army War College]], he commanded the 3rd Brigade, 82nd Airborne Division at Fort Bragg, North Carolina.<ref name="auto1" />

title: Lloyd Austin
deleted: On September 1, 2010, Austin became Commanding General (CG) of [[United States Forces – Iraq]] (USF-I) at a ceremony at [[Al-Faw Palace]] in Baghdad. He took over from General [[Ray Odierno]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.army.mil/article/44757/austin_leads_usf_i_into_new_dawn|title=Austin leads USF-I into New Dawn|last=Dey|first=Roger M.|publisher=[[United States Army]]|access-date=2016-05-18|date=2010-09-04|archive-date=January 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190126232248/https://www.army.mil/article/44757/austin_leads_usf_i_into_new_dawn|url-status=live}}</ref>{{sfn|Gordon|Trainor|2013|p=637}} As CG, USF-I, Austin was the senior military commander in charge of all US and remaining coalition forces in Iraq.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usf-iraq.com/usf-iraq-commanding-general/|title=USF-Iraq Commanding General|date=2010-12-05|publisher=[[United States Forces – Iraq]]|access-date=2020-12-02|archive-date=October 20, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201020144545/https://www.usf-iraq.com/usf-iraq-commanding-general/|url-status=live}}</ref> Their mission was to advise, train, assist, and equip the [[Iraqi Armed Forces]] and the security agencies part of the [[Ministry of Interior (Iraq)|Ministry of the Interior]]. As commander, Austin requested an additional troop presence in Iraq from 14,000 to 18,000.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Singh|first=Robert|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQnrSo2YyTEC&pg=PA106|title=Barack Obama's Post-American Foreign Policy: The Limits of Engagement|year=2012|publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-78093-113-5|page=106|language=en|access-date=December 8, 2020|archive-date=December 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208212744/https://books.google.com/books?id=YQnrSo2YyTEC&pg=PA106|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: Lloyd Austin
added: Austin was the second former [[United States Central Command|CENTCOM Commander]] after General [[Jim Mattis|James Mattis]] who later on would serve as [[United States Secretary of Defense]]. Both Austin and Mattis was once CENTCOM Commander, Mattis was succeeded by Austin following Mattis retirement as CENTCOM Commander in 2013 and served as the 26th U.S. Secretary of Defense.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rej|first=Abhijnan|date=January 23, 2021|title=US Senate Confirms Lloyd Austin as Secretary of Defense|url=https://thediplomat.com/2021/01/us-senate-confirms-lloyd-austin-as-secretary-of-defense/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=January 27, 2021|website=thediplomat.com}}</ref>

title: Lloyd Austin
deleted: Austin's nomination, and the attendant requirement for a waiver, met with concern in Congress regarding its implications for [[civil–military relations]].<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Steinhauer|first1=Jennifer|last2=Schmitt|first2=Eric|last3=Broadwater|first3=Luke|date=2020-12-08|title=Biden's Pentagon Pick Reignites Debate Over Civilian Control of Military|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/08/us/politics/biden-austin-defense-secretary.html|access-date=2020-12-09|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=December 9, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201209004250/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/08/us/politics/biden-austin-defense-secretary.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Desiderio|first1=Andrew|last2=O'Brien|first2=Connor|date=2020-12-08|title=Democrats signal early opposition to Biden's Defense pick|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/08/democrats-opposition-biden-defense-pick-443689|access-date=2020-12-09|work=[[Politico]]|language=en|archive-date=December 9, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201209164017/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/08/democrats-opposition-biden-defense-pick-443689|url-status=live}}</ref> Former Secretary of Defense [[Robert Gates]] and former Secretary of State [[Colin Powell]], among others, issued statements supporting Austin's nomination.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Crowley|first1=Michael|last2=Schmitt|first2=Eric|date=2020-12-10|title=Biden Asks Congress to Grant Waiver for 'Cool Under Fire' Defense Pick|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/09/us/politics/biden-lloyd-austin-pentagon-waiver.html|access-date=2020-12-10|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=December 10, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201210033739/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/09/us/politics/biden-lloyd-austin-pentagon-waiver.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Democratic Representative [[Seth Moulton]] opposed it.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Seligman|first1=Lara|last2=Bender|first2=Bryan|last3=O'Brien|first3=Connor|title=New cracks emerge among Democrats over Biden's Pentagon pick|date=December 23, 2020|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/23/lloyd-austin-confirmation-jeopardy-450307|access-date=2020-12-24|work=[[Politico]]|language=en|archive-date=December 24, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201224034600/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/23/lloyd-austin-confirmation-jeopardy-450307|url-status=live}}</ref>

The [[Senate Armed Services Committee]] held a confirmation hearing for Austin on January 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Connor|date=2021-01-21|title=Senate clears Austin waiver, setting up confirmation vote to be Biden's Pentagon chief|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/21/austin-waiver-approved-senate-461082|access-date=2021-01-21|work=[[Politico]]|language=en|archive-date=January 23, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210123050218/https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/21/austin-waiver-approved-senate-461082|url-status=live}}</ref> On January 21, Congress granted Austin a waiver of the seven-year requirement, by a 326–78 vote in the House and a 69–27 vote in the Senate.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|last=Youssef|first=Nancy A.|date=2021-01-21|title=Lloyd Austin Receives Waiver Allowing Him to Become Defense Chief|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/lawmakers-approve-waiver-allowing-lloyd-austin-to-become-defense-chief-11611269413|access-date=2021-01-21|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=January 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122172905/https://www.wsj.com/articles/lawmakers-approve-waiver-allowing-lloyd-austin-to-become-defense-chief-11611269413|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=H.R.335 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): To provide for an exception to a limitation against appointment of persons as Secretary of Defense within seven years of relief from active duty as a regular commissioned officer of the Armed Forces. |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/335 |website=www.congress.gov |date=22 January 2021}}</ref> He was confirmed by the Senate in a 93–2 vote on January 22, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Lloyd Austin Confirmed As Secretary of Defense, Becomes First Black Pentagon Chief|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/president-biden-takes-office/2021/01/22/959581977/lloyd-austin-confirmed-as-secretary-of-defense-becomes-first-black-pentagon-chie|access-date=2021-01-22|website=NPR.org|language=en|archive-date=January 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122172906/https://www.npr.org/sections/president-biden-takes-office/2021/01/22/959581977/lloyd-austin-confirmed-as-secretary-of-defense-becomes-first-black-pentagon-chie|url-status=live}}</ref> Republican Senators [[Josh Hawley]] and [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]] were the only no votes. Upon his confirmation and swearing-in later that day, Austin became the first Black secretary of defense.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|last=Edmondson|first=Catie|date=2021-01-22|title=Lloyd Austin is confirmed, becoming the first Black defense secretary in U.S. history.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/22/us/lloyd-austin-confirmed.html|access-date=2021-01-22|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=January 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122171921/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/22/us/lloyd-austin-confirmed.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Austin took office on January 22, 2021, after being sworn in by a defense department official, and was sworn in ceremonially by Vice President Kamala Harris on January 25, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Everstine|first=Brian W.|date=2021-01-25|title=Austin Ceremonially Sworn in at the White House|url=https://www.airforcemag.com/austin-ceremonially-sworn-in-at-the-white-house/|access-date=2021-01-26|website=Air Force Magazine|language=en-US}}</ref>
